Tiger kills keeper at Hamilton Zoo A tiger attack saw Hamilton Zoo locked down on Sunday.
PT0M50S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Tiger kills zookeeper Thousands of people are calling for the life of a Sumatran tiger to be spared, following the death of a zookeeper in Hamilton, New Zealand.
The zoo's male tiger Oz mauled Samantha Lynda Kudeweh, 43, on Sunday morning.
Hamilton Zoo curator Samantha Kudeweh has been fondly remembered by colleagues after a fatal attack by a tiger at the zoo. Photo: Bruce Mercer
Ms Kudeweh, a mother of two, who worked in Melbourne in the early 2000s, had 20 years' experience as a keeper.
Advertisement Oz is in his enclosure and no decision has been announced as to his fate.
More than 4500 people have liked a Facebook page "Help save Oz the Sumatran Tiger at Hamilton Zoo NZ".
Tigers in their enclosure at Hamilton Zoo. Photo: Hamilton Zoo
Hundreds have also posted tributes on Hamilton Zoo's page, with many calling for Oz's life to be spared.
"Condolences to the keeper's family, colleagues and friends. Working with wild animals comes with known risks, please don't kill the tiger for being a tiger," Becky Moorhead wrote.
Jennifer Conaghan posted, "She was an amazing lady and had the respect of the regional zoo industry. My thoughts are with you all."
Hamilton City Council chief executive Richard Briggs said it's a difficult situation for staff and Ms Kudeweh's family.
The council is focusing on supporting them, while the investigations are completed, he said.
Police, WorkSafe and the Ministry of Primary Industries are investigating and the zoo has been closed until Thursday.
Ms Kudeweh was a curator at the zoo, organising imports and exports.
In a profile on the zoo's website she said her favourite animal was the rhino.
Her family gathered at her Waikato home to console her husband, Richard, and children Billy, 9, and Sage, 3,
Ms Kudeweh had worked at Auckland Zoo for eight years and zoos in Australia for two before working in Hamilton.
She was recognised and respected globally as a talented, passionate and highly knowledgeable conservation and zoo professional whose expertise and understanding of animals was highly sought after by other zoos and captive animal breeding programmes, her colleague Catherine Nichols said.
Her role as curator at Hamilton Zoo made her second-in-charge to the zoo director, and she was responsible for the management of the animals and acquisitions of new animal exhibits.
"Samantha was a passionate conservationist, and today her family have recalled how, as an intermediate school student, she told her parents she wanted to work in the zoo sector," Ms Nichols said.
Ms Kudeweh worked at Auckland Zoo for several years, before a shift to Zoos Victoria in 2002.
During her stay in Melbourne, she met Richard Kudeweh, another zoo professional whom she would go on to marry.
In 2005, the couple moved to Hamilton Zoo, where she started as the mammals team leader. In 2011 she was promoted to zoo curator, achieving one of her professional dreams. It gave her the opportunity to become involved in a number of species management programmes, an area of conservation for which she had a passion.
She was responsible for managing breeding programmes for a number of species, including the southern white rhino, and was able to influence the zoo sector across Australasia.
She was NZFaunaTAG co-convener (birds), a nationwide programme to help rebuild populations of native species.
AAP, Stuff,co.nz
